head.title: HTML Elements
head.description: An HTML element usually consists of a start tag and end tag, with the content inserted in between

data: <tagname>Content goes here...</tagname>
The HTML element is everything from the start tag to the end tag:
<p>My first paragraph.</p>

Start tag Element content End tag
<h1> My First Heading </h1>
<p> My first paragraph. </p>

HTML elements with no content are called empty elements. Empty elements do not have an end tag, such as the
element (which indicates a line break).
HTML elements can be nested (elements can contain elements).
All HTML documents consist of nested HTML elements.
This example contains four HTML elements:

body.title: Example
data:
My First Heading

My first paragraph.
The <html> element defines the whole document.
It has a start tag <html> and an end tag </html>.
The element content is another HTML element (the <body> element).

My First Heading

My first paragraph.
The <body> element defines the document body.
It has a start tag <body> and an end tag </body>.
The element content is two other HTML elements (<h1> and <p>).

My First Heading

My first paragraph.
The <h1> element defines a heading.
It has a start tag <h1> and an end tag </h1>.
The element content is: My First Heading.
My First Heading
The <p> element defines a paragraph.
It has a start tag <p> and an end tag </p>.
The element content is: My first paragraph.
My first paragraph.
